case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Official Trustee of Bengal

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2358-2366 of 1968 and 1174, 1288-1299 of 1971 were filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2358-2366, of 1968 1174, 1288-1299 of 1971.

facts.text: The appeals arise from the judgment and order dated 4th January 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 25 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and Order dated the 4th January, 1966 of the, Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 25 of 1968.

facts.text: In the year 1820 Smt. Chitra Dassi executed an Ekrarnama making a gift of a piece of land for religious purposes.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1820 one Smt. Chitra Dassi executed an Ekrarnama making a gift of a piece of land for religious Purposes.

facts.text: In 1842 Smt. Chitra Dassi executed a will referring to the earlier debutter of the property and directed her four sons to perform the daily service of Sri Radhagobindjee.

anchor.surface_text: In 1842 she executed a will referring to the fact that she had-earlier made the property debutter and directed her four sons, the executors, to perform the daily service of Sri Radhagobindjee.

facts.text: Smt. Chitra Dassi died in 1855.

anchor.surface_text: She died in 1855.

facts.text: In 1876 a suit was filed in the Calcutta High Court praying that the trust should be administered and a scheme prepared.

anchor.surface_text: In 1876 a suit was filed in the Calcutta High Court praying that the trust should be administered by the companyrt and a scheme prepared.

facts.text: Subsequently there were a number of applications made from time to time and a number of orders were made on them.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, there were a number of applications made from time to time and a number of orders were also made on them.

facts.text: In 1929 a scheme of administration was framed.

anchor.surface_text: In 1929 a scheme of administration was framed and a little later the

facts.text: Official Trustee of Bengal was appointed to be the trustee of the debutter estate.

anchor.surface_text: Official Trustee of Bengal was appointed to be the trustee of the said debutter estate.

facts.text: After the Official Trustee took possession, he was assessed in respect of the income of the debutter estate in the status of an individual under section 41 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: After the- official trustee took possession of the properties he was assessed in respect of the income of the debutter estate in the status of an individual under section 41 of the Act.

facts.text: In respect of assessment years 1939-40 to 1942-43 a reference was made under section 66(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the assessment years 1939-40 to 1942-43 a reference was made under section 66 2  of the Act.

facts.text: A Bench of the Calcutta High Court held that the property should be held to be a religious trust.

anchor.surface_text: A Bench of the Calcutta High Court held that upon a proper companystruction of the, relevant documents and the scheme sanctioned and orders passed by the High Court the property should be held to be a religious trust.

facts.text: The matter went up to the High Court again in respect of assessment years 1943-44 to 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The matter again went up to the High Court in respect of the assessment years 194344 to 1951-52.

facts.text: High Court considered three questions: Q1 on whether trust or dedication to deity; Q2 if trust, whether public benefit; Q3 if Thakur liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Three questions finally came to be companysidered by the High Court Q.1 Whether upon a proper companystruction of the relevant documents executed by Smt. Chitra Dassi and the relevant schemes sanctioned and orders passed by the High Court, there was a trust in favour of the Deity or whether there was a dedication of the properties -to the Deity ? Q.2 Alternatively, if the dedication to the Thakur companystitute trust, is it a religious trust which did number enure to the benefit of the public ? Q.3 Is the Thakur Radha Gobinda Jew liable to assessment under the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: On Q1, High Court held there was dedication to the deity but no trust in technical English sense.

anchor.surface_text: On question No. 1 the High Court held that upon a proper companystruction of the relevant documents executed by Chitra Dassi and the relevant Schemes sanctioned and orders passed by the High Court there was a dedication of the properties to the deity, but that there was numbertrust in the technical sense, that is to say, as understood in the English law.

facts.text: Both parties agreed that in Q2 'trust' did not mean technical English sense.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the first part of the 2nd question both parties before the High Court agreed that in that question the word trust did number mean a trust in the technical or the English sense.

facts.text: High Court held the endowment is a private religious trust with no public benefit except one order for feeding the poor.

anchor.surface_text: On the second part of the question it was held that the endowment is a private religious trust and the documents creating it or companyfirming it grant numberbenefit to the members of the public, that an order made by the Calcutta High Court by which certain directions were given for feeding the poor, was the only instance in which a benefit enured to the public.

facts.text: High Court held the deity is liable to assessment as an individual under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the 3rd question the High Court elaborately discussed whether the deity companyld be held to be an individual and held that the deity was liable to assessment under the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court considered only whether deity is an individual.

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court the only point argued was whether the High Court was right in companying to the companyclusion that the deity is an individual.

facts.text: Supreme Court followed Jogendra Nath Naskar v Commr. of Income-tax (1969) 74 ITR 33 holding Hindu deity is individual under section 3.

anchor.surface_text: When the High Court dealt with this question it did number have the benefit of the decision of this Court in Jogendra Nath Naskar v Commr. of Income-tax  1969-74 ITR 33  wherein it was held that a Hindu deity falls within the meaning of the word individual in section 3 and can be treated as a unit of assessment.

facts.text: Appellant urged that Jogendra Nath decision was wrong and should be reconsidered.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee arguing for the appellant urged that decision was wrong and should, be reconsidered.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with Jogendra Nath decision.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

facts.text: It was conceded by appellant that if 'person' used instead of 'individual', deity would be person as juristic person.

anchor.surface_text: it was companyceded before us on behalf of the appellant that if the word used had been a person instead of an individual the deity would be a person because a person will include a juristic person.

facts.text: Hindu deity is a juristic person capable of holding property.

anchor.surface_text: That a Hindu deity is a juristic person is a well established proposition and has been so for a long time.

facts.text: The appeals are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether a Hindu deity is an individual within the meaning of that word under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in these,appeals is whether a Hindu deity is an individual within the meaning, of that word under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

arguments.court_reasoning: Amendment Act 1939 retained 'individual' despite changing 'association of individuals' to 'association of persons', indicating deliberate choice not to broaden to 'person'.

arguments.claim: The word 'individual' denotes only a male or female human being.

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Sodra Devi 32 ITR 615 it was pointed out that the word individual not only means a human being but also includes a corporation created by a statute... But Dass J. observed there is no difficulty whatsoever in my opinion, in giving the word individual its natural meaning, that is, that the word means either a male or a female.

arguments.court_reasoning: Case not concerned with juridical entity like deity.

arguments.claim: A Hindu deity is an individual.

anchor.surface_text: Mukharji J. of the Calcutta High Court in I T. Commr. v. Jogendra Nath AIR 1965 Cal. 570 held that a Hindu deity can be either an individual or a person or both. The same High Court in Sri Sridhar v. L T. Officer AIR 1966 Cal. 494 held that a Hindu idol is a juristic entity who is given the status of a human being capable of having property and it can be called an individual.

arguments.claim: There is no reason why a Hindu deity's income should be outside taxation if it can be brought within the statutory language without strain.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that as a Hindu deity can hold property and be in receipt of income and can also sue and be sued in a court of law there is no reason why its income should be held to be outside the ambit of taxation if it can be brought within it without straining the language of the statutory provision.

holdings.text: A Hindu deity falls within the meaning of the word individual in section 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 and can be treated as a unit of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: When the High Court dealt with this question it did number have the benefit of the decision of this Court in Jogendra Nath Naskar v Commr. of Income-tax  1969-74 ITR 33  wherein it was held that a Hindu deity falls within the meaning of the word individual in section 3 and can be treated as a unit of assessment. Mr. Chatterjee arguing for the appellant urged that decision was wrong and should, be reconsidered. We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court expressly agrees with binding precedent in Jogendra Nath Naskar; rejects petitioner's call to reconsider; affirms via juristic person status, capacity to hold property/receive income/sue/be sued, and purposive reading without straining statutory language; distinguishes contrary interpretations in Ahmedabad Mill Owners Association and Sodra Devi as inapplicable to juridical entities like deities.

holdings.text: The Thakur Radha Gobinda Jew is liable to assessment under the Indian Income-tax Act as an individual.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the 3rd question the High Court elaborately discussed whether the deity companyld be held to be an individual and held that the deity was liable to assessment under the Income-tax Act. Before this Court the only point argued was whether the High Court was right in companying to the companyclusion that the deity is an individual. ... We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's conclusion on deity's taxability by agreeing with Jogendra precedent and providing supporting analysis on juristic status and statutory fit; results in dismissal of appeals challenging this finding.

holdings.text: A Hindu deity is a juristic person capable of holding property, receiving income, suing and being sued.

anchor.surface_text: That a Hindu deity is a juristic person is a well established proposition and has been so for a long time. In Maharanee Shibessouree Debia v. Mothooranath Acharjo  1869 13 MIA 270  it was observed The Talook itself, with which these Jimmas were companynected by tenure, was dedicated to the religious services, of the Idol. ... The authorities thus amply establish that a Hindu deity is a juristic person capable of holding property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on long line of binding precedents from Privy Council, High Courts confirming deity's juridical status analogous to natural persons for property and legal rights.

holdings.text: There is no reason why a Hindu deity's income should be held outside the ambit of taxation if it can be brought within the statutory provision without straining the language.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that as a Hindu deity can hold property and be in receipt of income and can also sue and be sued in a companyrt of law there is numberreason why its income should be held to be outside the ambit of taxation if it can be brought within it without straining the language of the statutory provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Draws on deity's practical capacities as juristic entity to support textual/purposive inclusion as 'individual' for tax assessment via shebaits.

holdings.text: The problem whether a Hindu deity is an 'individual' is not likely to arise after the Income-tax Act, 1961, as section 2(31) defines 'person' to include every artificial juridical person.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, mention that the problem whether the Hindu deity is an individual is number likely to arise after the enactment of Income-tax Act, 1961 which in clause 31 of section 2 defines a person as including  i  an individual,  ii  a Hindu undivided family.  iii  a companypany, a firm.  v  an association of persons or a body of individuals, whether incorporated or number,  vi  a local authority. and  vii  every artificial juridical person, number falling within any of the preceding sub-clauses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observes explicit statutory evolution post-1922 Act resolves ambiguity by including artificial juridical persons like deities in 'person'.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final determination upholding High Court judgment on all issues including deity's status as assessable individual based on above holdings.

anchor.surface_text: When the High Court dealt with this question it did number have the benefit of the decision of this Court in Jogendra Nath Naskar v Commr. of Income-tax  1969-74 ITR 33  wherein it was held that a Hindu deity falls within the meaning of the word individual in section 3 and can be treated as a unit of assessment. Mr. Chatterjee arguing for the appellant urged that decision was wrong and should, be reconsidered. We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

When the High Court dealt with this question it did number have the benefit of the decision of this Court in Jogendra Nath Naskar v Commr. of Income-tax  1969-74 ITR 33  wherein it was held that a Hindu deity falls within the meaning of the word individual in section 3 and can be treated as a unit of assessment. Mr. Chatterjee arguing for the appellant urged that decision was wrong and should, be reconsidered. We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the 3rd question the High Court elaborately discussed whether the deity companyld be held to be an individual and held that the deity was liable to assessment under the Income-tax Act. Before this Court the only point argued was whether the High Court was right in companying to the companyclusion that the deity is an individual. ... We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

As regards the 3rd question the High Court elaborately discussed whether the deity companyld be held to be an individual and held that the deity was liable to assessment under the Income-tax Act. Before this Court the only point argued was whether the High Court was right in companying to the companyclusion that the deity is an individual. ... We find ourselves in entire agreement with the decision of this Court referred to above.

That a Hindu deity is a juristic person is a well established proposition and has been so for a long time. In Maharanee Shibessouree Debia v. Mothooranath Acharjo  1869 13 MIA 270  it was observed The Talook itself, with which these Jimmas were companynected by tenure, was dedicated to the religious services, of the Idol. ... The authorities thus amply establish that a Hindu deity is a juristic person capable of holding property.
